channel.title: Halp, JFrame!
channel.description:
I have an image (map) that is 2000x2000 and my frame size is 500x700; I want to be able to move my character around the frame where the map moves with the player so that it does not look like the player is moving off screen but it looks like the player is walking around the image.
Any ideas how?

[/quote]2000x2000 in a 500x700 frame doesnt need to be split up

That is assuming the map will not become larger or doesn’t have regions you cannot travel to.[/quote]
There will be other regions such as dungeons etc., that are loaded on demand.

item.title: Halp, JFrame!
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

I’m not sure how you’re doing stuff so far, but I’m assuming you’re using AWT inside the JFrame? So you have a call to a method somewhere that paints an image to the screen at some x,y position? If you paint to a more negative x,y position this will make it look like the player is moving downwards and towards the right (assuming x,y are zero at the top left… I can’t remember how AWT does it off the top of my head).

Just do that to get started, and then work on extra stuff like camera movement after.

Read full topic

item.title: Halp, JFrame!
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

Ambokile:

Keeping the player centred and moving the map around as they move would probably be best (and if they’re within 250 or 350 blocks of the side of the map, THEN move the player)

That would move the map sure, but I want the player to be able to actually be able to move around the frame (also there will be multiple players in game too). I wanted the map to show when the player reaches like 100px from the edge.

HcoJustin:

Please don’t keep the entire map loaded. Split it up into regions and as you near the border make the transition if there is another region to travel to.

I rather not have it transition, but it’ll probby be a last resort if I cannot get my current idea working.

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:5, topic:536507”]Yeah, loading chunks of that shit from disk would incur a higher latency at almost zero memory saving.

Keep the model and the view separate. Store the players x,y position in terms of the actual position on the map, and then render the map based on this with the player in the centre. You’ll end up painting to negative coordinates to get the shit over to the left and upwards. If there is something you can optimise, it’ll be chunking the map image in memory so that you don’t have to paint the entire shebang.[/quote]
I don’t understand what you mean? I already get negative coords by just having a blank JFrame.

Read full topic

[quote=“Davidi2, post:4, topic:536507”][quote author=HcoJustin link=topic=655320.msg4387792#msg4387792 date=1386310702]
Please don’t keep the entire map loaded. Split it up into regions and as you near the border make the transition if there is another region to travel to.
[/quote]2000x2000 in a 500x700 frame doesnt need to be split up[/quote]Yeah, loading chunks of that shit from disk would incur a higher latency at almost zero memory saving.

Keep the model and the view separate. Store the players x,y position in terms of the actual position on the map, and then render the map based on this with the player in the centre. You’ll end up painting to negative coordinates to get the shit over to the left and upwards. If there is something you can optimise, it’ll be chunking the map image in memory so that you don’t have to paint the entire shebang.
